evaluation_results.original_answer: From 2022 to 2024, Lowe's consistently defined ROIC using Lease Adjusted NOPAT as a non-GAAP metric, dividing it by the average of current and prior year debt and shareholders' equity/deficit. In 2022, Lease Adjusted NOPAT was introduced as a key component of ROIC to reflect the impact of lease obligations on operating profits. In 2023, the company maintained the same methodology but added a note clarifying the tax implications of adjustments made to arrive at adjusted diluted EPS, signaling a more nuanced approach to reconciling GAAP and non-GAAP figures. The only changes were the updated lease‑interest amounts, the lower effective tax rates (28.8 % → 24.1 % → 24.0 %) and the diminishing impact of the Canadian‑retail‑business sale, which reduced lease liabilities over time.  This consistency shows Lowe’s disciplined, transparent approach to capital efficiency: it treats lease obligations as part of invested capital and explicitly incorporates lease interest into operating profit, ensuring ROIC reflects the true cost of capital even as lease commitments evolve.
